Pick your movie of the week: 20’s Pixar (June 23-29, 2024)

To me, Inside Out was the best Pixar movie of the last decade. Just last weekend I saw the sequel with Joy, Leah, and Ehsas; and again, for me it is so far the best Pixar of the 20’s. The nominees this week are Pixar movies released in the last 4 years. I enjoyed each of these quite a bit. How about you? Vote for one to be our movie of the week by voting with a comment:

Soul (2020)

Luca (2021)

Turning Red (2022)

Honourable mentions to Alan Grant (Sam Neil) in Jurassic Park, John Keating (Robin Williams) in Dead Poets Society (1989), and Frankie Dunn (Clint Eastwood) in Million Dollar Baby (2004).

Conspiracy Theories: it’s what I heard anyway…

I was listening to a podcast recently that brought to light some pretty wild conspiracy theories that I hadn’t heard of. I want to share some of the wackiest ones with you, but first let’s acknowledge big ones. Would this be an accurate top 10 of the most famous and most talked about conspiracy theories?

Elvis and/or Hitler still alive

Princess Diana death planned

Climate change as a hoax

Flat earth

The Illuminati or New World Order

9/11 as an inside job

Moon landing as a hoax

Aliens active on earth (Building the pyramids, Stonehenge, etc.)

COVID-19

JFK

Some are understandable, other are pure lunacy. But never mind those. Let’s get to the main course: the wild ones that I hadn’t heard about until just recently. Perhaps you have. Either way, read carefully. You never know who’s watching!

Pandas aren’t real – Yup. This conspiracy says that pandas couldn’t make it as a species because 1) they’re bad at reproducing, 2) they are clumsy, and 3) they eat nothing but bamboo even though they’re built like carnivores. Therefore, according to believers, they are just people in panda suits putting on a show for us all. There are a lot of pandas in this world, in zoos across the globe and in the wild of China. So, like what is found in a lot of conspiracy theories, this is one very elaborate and expensive hoax to pull off.

Earth is hollow – Scientists had released information about the earth’s make-up in 2014, and in it shared that little is actually known about the earth’s core. Therefore, of course, creative minds took it and ran. Not only do some say it’s hollow, others claim there is another earth inside of the earth.

Avril Lavigne died and was replaced by a girl named Melissa – According to this theory, Lavigne took her own life under the pressures that come with worldwide fame as well as the death of her grandfather. A lookalike and voice-alike clone was then found to replace her so that money could still be made. One of their main arguments of adherents to this theory is that Lavigne hasn’t produced songs as good as the ones before that time. Similar to, and equally as nonsensical as, the belief that Paul McCartney died in 1966 and was replaced by a lookalike/sound-alike. And in that storyline, the band was gracious enough to leave us clues on their album covers so we could know the truth.

Britney Spears was an agent on George W. Bush’s payroll – The idea here is that she was staging some of her craziest moments to distract everyone from the failures and blunders made by the Bush administration. In 2004, when one of his staff leaked the name of a undercover CIA agent, Britney went to Vegas, partied, and got married. When Cheney accidentally shot a friend, she almost dropped her baby and stole the spotlight. When Bush made a bewildering announcement of a “reformation of Al-Qaeda,” she shaved her head. Then when Obama won the 2008 election, she began her comeback releasing her Circus album, as if celebrating that she was done serving.

Malala Yousafzai a Western spy – Yousafzai has been a hero of women’s education and women’s rights in Pakistan for more than a decade. The conspiracy theory could believably be an attempt to undermine her influence, as it claims that her attempted murder (shot in the face by the Taliban) was staged or made up as a way to discredit the Taliban. And somehow, all of this was carried out by the CIA, her own father, and Robert de Niro.

Chemtrails – You know how when you see planes flying overhead they leave what looks like a long trail of exhaust? It’s apparently a mix of fuel and condensation, but there have long been suspicions held by conspiracy theorists that they are actually streaks of poison being emitted and falling to the earth. This is allegedly done by the government for different reasons. One of them I heard from a customer of mine while I worked on his vehicle. He said that it was pesticides to ruin farmers’ crops so that they can control how much they yield. Somehow it would also make the farmers more reliant on the government. You’d think someone getting in office would want to be a hero and blow the whistle.

Prince Charles is a vampire – I think this mainly had to do with him being a direct descendent of Vlad the Impaler, who was the inspiration of Brahm Stoker’s Dracula. That and Porphyria, a disease that makes its sufferers sensitive to sunlight, runs through his royal family. Surely enough evidence for all of us to be believers.

Harry Styles and Louis Tomlinson of One Direction a couple – I’m not sure if the “shippers” were fans or haters, but they spread the idea that these two band members were secretly a couple, appearing with women only to cover up their relationship. They both deny it, of course, but they do admit one thing: the conspiracy theory has made things weird when they’re together in the public eye.

The world ended in 2012 – This isn’t just the Mayan calendar prediction of the end of the world. This theory says that in 2012 Planet Earth was sucked into a black hole when CERN discovered the Higgs Boson particle that year. It claims that we all just haven’t realized this yet, either because we’re living in a simulation or because all of our minds are still active, causing us to think we’re alive as our remains are floating in space from the giant catastrophe.

Denver International Airport is headquarters for evil world-domination – There are gargoyles and strange murals throughout this airport. I’ve seen them myself. The murals are beautiful and tell a story of peace and restoration, but the few depictions of death and war made people sure that it had to do with the Illuminati. Even the artists who painted the murals lost out on valuable commissions after the mural was completed and rumours swirled. But that’s the thing about super secret groups of elites who plan to take over the world. They often mistakenly give clues that announce their presence.

Congratulations Don’t Look Up. This is your week.

And the Oscar goes to…

Best Actress: Julia Roberts as Alice Sutton, in Conspiracy Theory

Best Actor: Kevin Costner as Jim Garrison in JFK

Best Quote: “It’s called scotoma. The mind sees what it chooses to see.” – Ian McKellen as Sir Leigh Teabing in The Da Vinci Code

This is not to say any and all conspiracy theories are wrong. Reader’s Digest published an article on ones that turned out to be true. You can read it here.

Comedies: The Best in Every Category

A few weeks ago I was trying to come up with the “Mount Rushmore” of every movie genre, and I found comedy the hardest category. It may even be the most divisive category to come up with a shortlist of greats. This time, I’m going to try and identify the movies that I would guess to be the greatest of each subcategory of comedy movies.

HORROR COMEDY

The Contenders: Young Frankenstein (1974); Shaun of the Dead (2004); Beetlejuice (1988); Ghostbusters (1984)

My own personal favourite: Shaun of the Dead

The clear winner: Ghostbusters

TEEN COMEDY

The Contenders: Mean Girls (2024); Superbad (2007); Napoleon Dynamite (2004); Booksmart (2019); Bottoms (2023); Ten Things I Hate About You (1999)

My own personal favourite: Napoleon Dynamite

The clear winner: Mean Girls

MUSICAL COMEDY

The Contenders: Grease (1978); Hairspray (1988, 2007), La La Land (2016), The Little Shop of Horrors (1986), The Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975), Singin’ in the Rain (1952)

My own personal favourite: La La Land

The clear winner: Grease

ACTION COMEDY

The Contenders: The Last Action Hero (1993); Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle/The Next Level (2017-2019); True Lies (1994); The Blues Brothers (1980); The Nice Guys (2016)

My own personal favourite: The Nice Guys

The clear winner: True Lies

BUDDY COP COMEDY

The Contenders: The Other Guys (2010); 21/22 Jump Street (2012, 2014); The Nice Guys (2016); The Police Academy series; Lethal Weapon series (1987-1998); Hot Fuzz (2007)

My own personal favourite: Hot Fuzz

The clear winner: Lethal Weapon

SUPERHERO COMEDY

The Contenders: Deadpool trilogy (2016-2024); Thor: Ragnarok (2017); Guardians of the Galaxy (2014); Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (2023); Mystery Men (1999)

My own personal favourite: Deadpool trilogy

The clear winner: Deadpool trilogy

SCI FI COMEDY

The Contenders: Spaceballs (1987); Short Circuit (1986); Ghostbusters (1984); Groundhog Day (1993)

My own personal favourite: Groundhog Day

The clear winner: Spaceballs

CRIME COMEDY

The Contenders: The Wolf of Wall Street (2013); Raising Arizona (1987); Ocean’s Eleven (2001); Game Night (2018); Beverly Hills Cop (1984); Snatch (2000)

The clear winner: Ocean’s Eleven

ANIMATED COMEDY

The Contenders: Shrek (2001); Emperor’s New Groove (2000); The Lego Movie (2014), Fantastic Mr. Fox (2009); Ice Age (2002)

My own personal favourite: Fantastic Mr. Fox

The clear winner: Shrek

MOCKUMENTARY

The Contenders: This is Spinal Tap (1984); Best in Show (2000); Popstar: Never Stop Never Stopping (2016); Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006); What We Do in the Shadows (2014)

My own personal favourite: Borat

The clear winner: Borat

FANTASY COMEDY

The Contenders: The Princess Bride (1987); Barbie (2023); 13 Going On 30 (2004); Everything Everywhere All At Once (2022); Back to the Future (1985); Bill and Ted’s Excellent Adventure (1989)

My own personal favourite: Back to the Future

The clear winner: Back to the Future

HISTORICAL COMEDY

The Contenders: The Death of Stalin (2017); History of the World, Part I (1981); Life of Brian (1979); Monty Python and the Holy Grail (1975)

My own personal favourite: History of the World, Part I

The clear winner: Monty Python and the Holy Grail

CHRISTMAS COMEDY

The Contenders: How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000); National Lampoon’s Christmas Vacation (1989); A Christmas Story (1983); Elf (2003); Home Alone dualogy (1990, 1992)

My own personal favourite: Christmas Vacation

The clear winner: Christmas Vacation

MYSTERY COMEDY

The Contenders: The ‘Burbs (1989), They Cloned Tyrone (2023), Knives Out (2019), Glass Onion (2022), The Pink Panther series (1963-2009)

My own personal favourite: Knives Out

The clear winner: The ‘Burbs

SPORTS COMEDY

The Contenders: Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story (2004); Caddyshack (1980); Happy Gilmore (1996); A League of Their Own (1992); Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006); Slap Shot (1977)

And the Oscar goes to…

Yes, I even liked Pinocchio enough to watch it again (but not too many times, mind you…). So, it killed me to look at the bottom 10. I hate to see so many good movies sitting in those spots. But that’s just a testament to Hanks’ excellent run of great films.

Just Say Nope: Anti-drug movies

I loved going to youth group when I was a teenager. I remember us having a guest speaker one Sunday who mentioned that TV and movies “glorify” alcohol, drugs, and other evils. For the longest time I believed this. But looking back now, I’m not sure any motivational speaker, television PSA, or scary story was ever effective at being anti-drugs than movies.

I mean all through elementary school one could hardly go a week without hearing a lecture about the dangers of cigarettes. We heard about the diseases and how many lives they claim. We heard how many adults say they wished they’d never started. We had health textbooks illustrated with gruesome pictures. But as soon as we all entered grade 7, boom, every 12 year old had a ciggy between their teeth.

But movies are pretty darn effective in turning one away from drugs. Sure, they do depict drugs from time to time, which is very different from celebrating them. I count marijuana as an exception, case in point being Cheech and Chong. That’s another discussion for another day.

So here are the top 10 films that could cause anyone to just say nope!

And these are ranked according to effectiveness:

Flight (2012) – The master Denzel Washington as a pilot in a well told story of alcohol use disorder. The climax is one of those scenes that has been etched in my brain. I actually think about it often.

Amy (2015) – Most of us have heard about the tragic end of Amy Winehouse at only 27. So young, but so influential already. Taken too soon by a disease that can end a life faster than cancer.

Traffic (2000) – I was always a Benecio del Toro and Catherine Zeta-Jones fan after watching this movie. It’s an eye-opener with regards to drug trafficking more than drug use. But it’s gritty depiction of the subject helped viewers understand the wide scope of the problem.

Scarface (1983) – If Tony Montana can’t convince someone not to do cocaine, I’m not sure anyone will.

28 Days (2000) – This is probably my favourite Sandra Bullock movie. It doesn’t show much of the horrors of drug abuse, but it brings the viewer to a deeper sense of understanding and compassion for those in recovery.

Thirteen (2003) – The title refers to the age of the two main characters. You can see how easily things can accelerate in the wrong direction for impressionable young teenagers.

Beautiful Boy (2018) – Incredible movie. It is tragic in nature, and an important depiction of adducts and their loved ones.

The Basketball Diaries (1995) – An early Leonardo DiCaprio arguably made a bigger name for himself in this one than in What’s Eating Gilbert Grape (1993), which says a lot.

Trainspotting (1996) – For the first while, it seems like it’s a film that is making light of drug use, maybe even making it cool. Until it doesn’t… and wow, it’s effective.

Requiem for a Dream (2000) – This is a harrowing movie, not for the faint of heart. Like Thirteen, one can have a better understanding of how someone can so easily slip into a trap of addiction.

HONOURABLE MENTIONS: When a Man Loves a Woman (1994); The Lost Weekend (1945)

Congratulations Scarface. This is your week.

And the Oscar goes to…

Best Actress: Lindsay Lohan as Anna Coleman/Tess Coleman in Freaky Friday

Best Actor: Al Pacino as Tony Montana in Scarface

Best Quote: “To watch a strong man broken down is a terrible thing.” – Esther Scott as Bridget in The Birth of a Nation

We all have safeguards in our lives to protect us from addiction, but it can still happen to anyone. The most important thing is to not be ashamed to get help. We are all humans. We all struggle. There’s no shame in needing help, only in judging those who do.
